title: 109_s232
content: "Definitions." The curr_chunk provides definitions related to the Act, including the meaning of "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, "Reclamation" as the Bureau of Reclamation, and "Fish passage and screening facilities" as structures enabling fish to pass through water diversion systems. The curr_chunk defines terms related to water projects, including strategies for fish passage, federal reclamation projects, non-federal parties, and the Snake River Basin. The curr_chunk defines terms related to water projects in the Snake River Basin and the Columbia River Basin, including habitat improvements for aquatic plants and animals. The Secretary is authorized to plan, design, and construct fish passage and screening facilities or habitat improvements in the Columbia River Basin to meet obligations under the Endangered Species Act. The Act prohibits the acquisition of land for habitat improvements. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for fish passage and screening facilities at non-Federal water projects in the Columbia River Basin. The Federal share of costs should not exceed 75%, and non-Federal parties are required to pay the remaining share. The non-Federal party may contribute cash or in-kind services for fish passage and screening facilities. In-kind services must be documented and valued by the Secretary. Indian tribes are exempt from these requirements. Financial assistance will be provided through grant or cooperative agreements in compliance with relevant laws. The Secretary may impose terms and conditions to ensure performance and protect interests. Non-Federal parties must ensure performance, protect Federal investment in fish passage facilities, and comply with laws. They hold rights to facilities and are responsible for operation and maintenance, not a cost to Federal projects. SEC. 4. OTHER REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary may assist non-Federal parties with permits for water projects, comply with Federal laws, State water laws, and coordinate with relevant agencies. The Secretary may assist non-Federal parties, states of Idaho, Oregon, and Washington, and federally recognized Indian tribes in carrying out authorized programs. SEC. 5. INAPPLICABILITY OF FEDERAL RECLAMATION LAW. The Reclamation Act of 1902 and related Acts do not apply to non-Federal water projects with fish passage and screening facilities authorized by this Act. Expenditures made by the Secretary under this Act are non-reimbursable and non-returnable to the Treasury. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Appropriations are authorized as needed for this Act. Passed the Senate on July 26, 2005. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
